docs.title: Pumbaa 🐗
docs.text: A powerful CLI tool for interacting with Cromwell workflow engine and managing WDL (Workflow Description Language) files.

docs.title: What is Pumbaa?
docs.text:
Pumbaa provides an intuitive command-line interface to:

  • 🎯 Manage workflows with an interactive terminal dashboard (TUI)
  • 🔍 Debug workflows with detailed execution views and preemption analysis
  • 📦 Bundle WDL files with all dependencies into portable packages
  • 📊 View metadata, logs, timing in a user-friendly format

docs.title: Interactive Dashboard
docs.text:
Browse and manage all your workflows in a beautiful terminal UI with real-time updates:

pumbaa dashboard

docs.title: Debug View
docs.text:
Explore workflow execution in detail with an interactive tree view showing tasks, calls, and timing:

pumbaa workflow debug --id <workflow-id>

docs.title: WDL Bundling
docs.text:
Package your WDL workflow with all imports into a single distributable file:

pumbaa bundle --workflow main.wdl --output my-workflow

docs.title: Why Pumbaa?
docs.text:
• 💻 Terminal-first - Beautiful TUI interfaces for power users
  • 📦 Portable - Single binary with no dependencies
  • 🎨 User-friendly - Intuitive commands and a practical TUI for inspecting and debugging workflows

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: Pumbaa is a CLI tool for interacting with the Cromwell workflow engine and WDL files. The project follows Clean Architecture principles with a layered structure.

docs.title: Project Structure
docs.text:
├── cmd/cli/              # Application entry point
├── internal/             # Private application code
│   ├── application/      # Use cases (Application Layer)
│   ├── config/           # Configuration management
│   ├── container/        # Dependency injection container
│   ├── domain/           # Domain entities and interfaces (Domain Layer)
│   ├── infrastructure/   # External services adapters (Infrastructure Layer)
│   └── interfaces/       # UI adapters - CLI and TUI (Interface Layer)
└── pkg/wdl/              # Reusable WDL parsing library

docs.title: Domain Layer (internal/domain/)
docs.text:
Contains business entities and repository interfaces (ports).

  • workflow/: Workflow entities (Workflow, Call, Status), repository interface, and errors
  • bundle/: Bundle entities for WDL packaging

docs.title: Application Layer (internal/application/)
docs.text:
Contains use cases that orchestrate domain logic.

  • workflow/submit/: Workflow submission use case
  • workflow/metadata/: Metadata retrieval use case
  • workflow/abort/: Workflow abortion use case
  • workflow/query/: Workflow query use case
  • workflow/debuginfo/: Debug information parsing and tree building
  • bundle/create/: WDL bundle creation use case

docs.title: Infrastructure Layer (internal/infrastructure/)
docs.text:
Contains implementations of external services.

  • cromwell/: Cromwell API client implementing workflow.Repository

docs.title: Interface Layer (internal/interfaces/)
docs.text:
Contains adapters for user interaction.

  • cli/handler/: CLI command handlers
  • cli/presenter/: Output formatters
  • tui/dashboard/: Interactive workflow TUI dashboard
  • tui/debug/: Interactive debug TUI

docs.title: Shared Library (pkg/wdl/)
docs.text:
Reusable WDL parsing library with ANTLR-generated parser.

  • ast/: Abstract Syntax Tree definitions
  • parser/: ANTLR-generated lexer/parser
  • visitor/: AST visitor implementation

docs.title: Dependency Flow
docs.text:
interfaces → application → domain ← infrastructure
     ↓            ↓           ↑
  container (wires everything together)

docs.title: Key Patterns
docs.text:
1. Repository Pattern: workflow.Repository interface in domain, implemented by cromwell.Client
  2. Use Case Pattern: Each operation is a separate use case with Execute() method
  3. Dependency Injection: container.Container wires all dependencies

docs.title: 1. Handler depends on Infrastructure directly
docs.text:
Location: internal/interfaces/cli/handler/debug.go, dashboard.go

Issue: DebugHandler and DashboardHandler receive *cromwell.Client directly instead of an interface.

// Current (violates DIP)
type DebugHandler struct {
    client *cromwell.Client
}

// Should be
type DebugHandler struct {
    repo workflow.Repository  // or a specific interface
}

Impact: Cannot test handlers in isolation, tight coupling to Cromwell implementation.

docs.title: 2. Missing Use Case for Debug/Dashboard
docs.text:
Location: internal/interfaces/cli/handler/debug.go, dashboard.go

Issue: These handlers call cromwell.Client methods directly, bypassing the application layer. Other handlers (submit, metadata, abort, query) correctly use use cases.

Impact: Business logic leaks into interface layer, inconsistent architecture.

docs.title: 3. debuginfo package has mixed responsibilities
docs.text:
Location: internal/application/workflow/debuginfo/

Issue: This package contains: - Metadata parsing (should be infrastructure or domain) - Tree building (presentation logic, should be in TUI layer) - Types that duplicate domain entities

Impact: Violates Single Responsibility Principle, hard to test and maintain.

docs.title: 4. TUI depends on debuginfo types directly
docs.text:
Location: internal/interfaces/tui/debug/types.go

Issue: TUI uses type aliases from debuginfo package: 

type TreeNode = debuginfo.TreeNode
type CallDetails = debuginfo.CallDetails

Impact: Application layer types leak into interface layer. Should use dedicated view models.

docs.title: 5. Container exposes concrete types
docs.text:
Location: internal/container/container.go

Issue: Container exposes *cromwell.Client instead of workflow.Repository interface.

// Current
CromwellClient *cromwell.Client

// Should be
WorkflowRepo workflow.Repository

Impact: Handlers can bypass the interface and use concrete implementation details.

docs.title: 6. preemption package location
docs.text:
Location: internal/domain/workflow/preemption/

Issue: Contains analysis logic that might be better suited in application layer, as it's not a core domain concept but rather a derived analysis.

Impact: Domain layer contains application-level logic.

docs.title: 7. Submit UseCase reads files directly
docs.text:
Location: internal/application/workflow/submit/usecase.go

Issue: Use case calls os.ReadFile() directly instead of receiving file contents.

// Current
workflowSource, err := os.ReadFile(input.WorkflowFile)

// Should receive content or use a FileReader interface

Impact: Hard to test, use case has I/O responsibilities.

docs.title: Recommended Refactoring Priority
docs.text:
1. High: Create interfaces for DebugHandler/DashboardHandler dependencies
  2. High: Create proper use cases for debug and dashboard features
  3. Medium: Move tree building logic to TUI layer, keep only parsing in debuginfo
  4. Medium: Use interfaces in Container instead of concrete types
  5. Low: Refactor Submit UseCase to not read files directly
  6. Low: Review preemption package location

docs.title: CI Migration: GitHub Actions
docs.text:
The project has been migrated from CircleCI to GitHub Actions. The previous CircleCI configuration (which uploaded coverage to Codecov) was removed and replaced by two GitHub Actions workflows:

  • ci.yml — Runs tests and builds on PRs / pushes to main, uploads the build and coverage artifacts to Actions artifacts (no external Codecov upload).
  • release.yml — Triggered on pushed Git tags (v*). Runs tests and then uses Goreleaser to create a release and attach signed build artifacts.

Goreleaser uses the repo's .goreleaser.yml to generate binaries for supported platforms. The release workflow uses the GITHUB_TOKEN secret (automatically provided by GitHub Actions) to create releases.

docs.title: Pumbaa TUI - Reference Guide
docs.text: This document describes the architecture and structure of the Pumbaa Terminal User Interface (TUI), a CLI tool for managing Cromwell workflows.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: The TUI is built using the Bubble Tea framework, following the Model-View-Update (MVU) pattern inspired by Elm. Styling is done with Lipgloss.

docs.title: Model-View-Update (MVU) Pattern
docs.text:
Each screen follows the Bubble Tea pattern:

type Model struct {
    // Application state
}

func (m Model) Init() tea.Cmd {
    // Initial command (data fetch, etc)
}

func (m Model) Update(msg tea.Msg) (tea.Model, tea.Cmd) {
    // Update state based on messages
}

func (m Model) View() string {
    // Render the interface
}

docs.title: Screen Coordination (app.go)
docs.text:
The AppModel coordinates navigation between screens:

type Screen int

const (
    ScreenDashboard Screen = iota
    ScreenDebug
)

type AppModel struct {
    currentScreen Screen
    dashboard     dashboard.Model
    debug         debug.Model
    // ...
}

func (m Model) handleXKeys(msg tea.KeyMsg) (Model, tea.Cmd) {

docs.title: Operações Assíncronas
docs.text:
// Command that returns a message
func (m Model) fetchData() tea.Cmd {
    return func() tea.Msg {
        data, err := m.fetcher.GetData(context.Background())
        if err != nil {
            return errorMsg{err}
        }
        return dataLoadedMsg{data}
    }
}

// In Update, handle the message
func (m Model) Update(msg tea.Msg) (tea.Model, tea.Cmd) {
    switch msg := msg.(type) {
    case dataLoadedMsg:
        m.data = msg.data
        return m, nil
    case errorMsg:
        m.error = msg.Error()
        return m, nil
    }
    return m, nil
}

docs.title: Bundle Creation
docs.text: Package WDL workflows with dependencies into ZIP files.

docs.title: Usage
docs.text: pumbaa bundle create --workflow FILE --output FILE

docs.title: Flags
docs.text: Flag Alias Required Description --workflow -w Yes Main WDL file --output -o Yes Output ZIP path

docs.title: How It Works
docs.text:
1. Parses main WDL file
  2. Finds all import statements
  3. Resolves import paths
  4. Packages all files into ZIP

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
Given workflow structure: 

pipeline.wdl
tasks/
  alignment.wdl
  calling.wdl

Create bundle: 

pumbaa bundle create \
  --workflow pipeline.wdl \
  --output bundle.zip

Submit with bundle: 

pumbaa workflow submit \
  --workflow pipeline.wdl \
  --dependencies bundle.zip

docs.title: Debug View
docs.text:
Inspect workflow execution tree and call-level details.

Note: the information shown depends on a working connection to your Cromwell server (set via --host or CROMWELL_HOST). If a subworkflow is collapsed, its metadata may be unavailable until you expand it (Pumbaa fetches it on demand).

docs.title: Usage
docs.text:
From dashboard: Press Enter on any workflow

CLI: 

pumbaa workflow debug <workflow-id>

docs.title: Keys
docs.text: Key Action ↑/↓ or k/j Navigate tree →/← or l/h Expand/collapse Enter or Space Toggle expand d Show call details o Show logs q or Esc Back

docs.title: Quick actions (1–4)
docs.text:
The details panel exposes quick actions for the selected call:

  • 1 — Inputs: open a modal showing call inputs.
  • 2 — Outputs: open a modal showing call outputs.
  • 3 — Command: open a modal showing the command executed by the call.
  • 4 — Logs: switch to the Logs view for the selected call. Logs can be loaded from Google Cloud Storage if your environment has Google Application Default Credentials configured (or from local paths when available).

In the modals you can press y to copy the displayed content to the system clipboard (works when the host environment provides a clipboard tool such as xclip, xsel, or wl-copy).

docs.title: Timing
docs.text: Press t to open the timeline (global timeline) for the selected workflow or subworkflow. To inspect a subworkflow's timing, navigate to the subworkflow in the tree and press t — Pumbaa will show a timeline for that workflow. Timing and task durations update as you fetch or expand subworkflows (again, this requires the Cromwell server to be reachable).

pumbaa workflow query --status Failed --status Aborting

docs.title: Filter by Name
docs.text: pumbaa workflow query --name variant-calling

docs.title: Combined
docs.text:
pumbaa workflow query \
  --name pipeline \
  --status Succeeded \
  --limit 10

docs.title: Status Values
docs.text:
• Submitted
  • Running
  • Succeeded
  • Failed
  • Aborting
  • Aborted

docs.title: Output
docs.text: Displays table with: - ID (first 8 chars) - Name - Status (color-coded) - Submission time

docs.title: See Also
docs.text:
• Dashboard - Interactive query
  • Metadata - Detailed workflow info

docs.title: Submit Workflows
docs.text: Submit WDL workflows to Cromwell.

docs.title: Usage
docs.text: pumbaa workflow submit --workflow FILE [OPTIONS]

docs.title: Flags
docs.text: Flag Alias Required Description --workflow -w Yes WDL workflow file --inputs -i No Inputs JSON file --options -o No Options JSON file --dependencies -d No Dependencies ZIP file --label -l No Labels (format: key=value)

docs.title: Basic
docs.text: pumbaa workflow submit --workflow hello.wdl

docs.title: With Inputs
docs.text:
pumbaa workflow submit \
  --workflow pipeline.wdl \
  --inputs inputs.json

docs.title: Complete
docs.text:
pumbaa workflow submit \
  --workflow analysis.wdl \
  --inputs inputs.json \
  --options options.json \
  --dependencies deps.zip \
  --label sample=S001 --label env=prod

docs.title: Input File
docs.text:
JSON format matching WDL inputs:

{
  "workflow.sample_name": "SAMPLE-001",
  "workflow.fastq": "gs://bucket/sample.fastq.gz",
  "workflow.reference": "gs://bucket/ref.fa"
}

docs.title: Options File
docs.text:
Configure workflow execution:

{
  "final_workflow_outputs_dir": "gs://bucket/outputs",
  "delete_intermediate_output_files": true,
  "write_to_cache": true,
  "read_from_cache": true
}

Common options: - final_workflow_outputs_dir - Output location - delete_intermediate_output_files - Cleanup - write_to_cache/read_from_cache - Call caching

docs.title: Dependencies
docs.text:
For workflows with imports, create ZIP with imported files:

# Using pumbaa
pumbaa bundle create --workflow workflow.wdl --output deps.zip

Submit with: 

pumbaa workflow submit --workflow workflow.wdl --dependencies deps.zip

docs.title: Labels
docs.text:
Organize workflows with labels:

pumbaa workflow submit \
  --workflow pipeline.wdl \
  --label sample=S001 \
  --label pipeline=variant-calling \
  --label user=$USER

Filter by labels in dashboard (press l).

docs.title: Response
docs.text:
Success: 

{
  "id": "abc12345-6789-0def-ghij-klmnopqrstuv",
  "status": "Submitted"
}

Use the ID to monitor: 

pumbaa dashboard                        # Interactive
pumbaa workflow debug <id>             # Debug view
pumbaa workflow query --id <id>        # CLI query

docs.title: See Also
docs.text:
• Bundle Creation
  • Dashboard
  • Debug View

docs.title: Configuration
docs.text: Pumbaa can be configured through command-line flags, environment variables, or a configuration file.

docs.title: Cromwell Server
docs.text: The most important configuration is your Cromwell server URL.

docs.title: Environment Variable (Recommended)
docs.text:
export CROMWELL_HOST=http://cromwell.example.com:8000

Add to your shell profile (~/.bashrc, ~/.zshrc, etc.) for persistence:

echo 'export CROMWELL_HOST=http://cromwell.example.com:8000' >> ~/.bashrc

docs.title: Command-Line Flag
docs.text:
pumbaa --host http://cromwell.example.com:8000 dashboard

Default value

The default host is http://localhost:8000.

docs.title: Configuration Priority
docs.text:
Settings are applied in this order (later overrides earlier):

  1. Default values
  2. Environment variables
  3. Command-line flags

docs.title: Authentication
docs.text:
Pumbaa assumes a direct connection to a reachable Cromwell server; it does not perform authentication itself.

If your Cromwell instance runs inside Kubernetes, expose it locally and point Pumbaa at localhost. Example using port-forward:

# forward the Cromwell service to local port 8000
kubectl -n <namespace> port-forward svc/cromwell 8000:8000

# then in another terminal
export CROMWELL_HOST=http://localhost:8000
pumbaa dashboard

You can also pass the host directly with --host:

pumbaa --host http://localhost:8000 dashboard

docs.text:

docs.title: Installation
docs.text: There are several ways to install Pumbaa depending on your platform and preferences.

docs.title: Quick Install (Recommended)
docs.text:
The easiest way to install Pumbaa on Linux or macOS:

curl -sSL https://raw.githubusercontent.com/lmtani/pumbaa/main/install.sh | bash

This script will:

  1. Detect your operating system and architecture
  2. Download the appropriate binary from GitHub Releases
  3. Install it to /usr/local/bin/pumbaa
  4. Make it executable

Verify Installation

After installation, verify it works: 

pumbaa --version

docs.title: Manual Download
docs.text: For more control over the installation:

docs.title: Step 1: Download
docs.text:
Visit GitHub Releases and download the appropriate binary for your platform:

Choose the release asset matching your OS and CPU architecture. Common assets on Releases are shown below:

Platform Architecture Release asset Linux x86_64 pumbaa_Linux_x86_64.tar.gz Linux ARM64 pumbaa_Linux_arm64.tar.gz macOS x86_64 pumbaa_Darwin_x86_64.tar.gz macOS ARM64 pumbaa_Darwin_arm64.tar.gz

Download the matching asset from the Releases page (replace the filename in the examples below with the one you downloaded).

docs.title: Step 2: Install
docs.text:
Linux/macOS 
# Download (replace URL with your platform)
# Example (tar.gz asset)
wget https://github.com/lmtani/pumbaa/releases/latest/download/pumbaa_Linux_x86_64.tar.gz

# Extract (creates `pumbaa` binary)
tar -xzf pumbaa_Linux_x86_64.tar.gz

# Make executable and install
chmod +x pumbaa
sudo mv pumbaa /usr/local/bin/pumbaa

docs.title: Permission Denied
docs.text:
If you get "permission denied" when running pumbaa:

chmod +x /path/to/pumbaa

docs.title: Command Not Found
docs.text:
Ensure the installation directory is in your PATH:

# Check current PATH
echo $PATH

# Add to PATH (add to ~/.bashrc or ~/.zshrc for persistence)
export PATH=$PATH:/usr/local/bin

docs.title: macOS Security Warning
docs.text:
On macOS, you might see a security warning. To allow the app:

  1. System Preferences → Security & Privacy → General
  2. Click "Allow Anyway" next to the pumbaa message
  3. Or run: xattr -d com.apple.quarantine /usr/local/bin/pumbaa

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text: Get up and running with Pumbaa in 5 minutes.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• Pumbaa installed (Installation Guide)
  • Access to a Cromwell server
  • (Optional) A WDL workflow file

docs.title: Step 1: Configure Cromwell Server
docs.text:
Set your Cromwell server URL:

export CROMWELL_HOST=http://localhost:8000

Tip

Add this to your ~/.bashrc or ~/.zshrc to persist across sessions.

docs.title: Step 2: Verify Connection
docs.text:
Test the connection to your Cromwell server:

pumbaa workflow query --limit 5

You should see a list of recent workflows (or an empty list if none exist).

docs.title: Step 3: Explore the Dashboard
docs.text:
Launch the interactive dashboard:

pumbaa dashboard

docs.title: Dashboard Navigation
docs.text:
• ↑/↓: Navigate through workflows
  • Enter: Open workflow in debug view
  • s: Filter by status (All/Running/Failed/Succeeded)
  • /: Filter by workflow name
  • a: Abort selected workflow
  • r: Refresh list
  • q: Quit

docs.title: Step 4: Submit a Workflow
docs.text:
If you have a WDL file, submit it:

pumbaa workflow submit \
  --workflow myworkflow.wdl \
  --inputs inputs.json

Example inputs.json:

{
  "myworkflow.input_file": "gs://bucket/data.txt",
  "myworkflow.sample_name": "sample-001"
}

docs.title: Query Specific Workflow
docs.text: pumbaa workflow query --status Running

docs.title: View Metadata
docs.text: pumbaa workflow metadata <workflow-id>

docs.title: Debug View
docs.text:
Open detailed execution view:

pumbaa workflow debug --id <workflow-id>

Navigate the debug view:

  • ↑/↓ or j/k: Navigate through tasks
  • ←/→ or h/l: Collapse/expand nodes
  • Enter: Toggle expand
  • Tab: Switch between tree and details panel
  • c: View command
  • i: View inputs
  • o: View outputs
  • L: View log paths
  • t: View task duration timeline
  • q: Return to dashboard

docs.title: Abort a Workflow
docs.text:
pumbaa workflow abort <workflow-id>

Or use the dashboard (press a on selected workflow).

docs.title: Bundle a WDL
docs.text:
Package your WDL with all imports:

pumbaa bundle --workflow main.wdl --output my-bundle

This creates: - my-bundle.wdl - Main workflow file - my-bundle.zip - All dependencies bundled

docs.title: "Connection refused"
docs.text:
Verify Cromwell is running:

curl $CROMWELL_HOST/api/workflows/v1/query

docs.title: "No workflows found"
docs.text:
Submit a test workflow:

# Use the example workflow
pumbaa workflow submit --workflow <simple-workflow>.wdl

docs.title: Dashboard not updating
docs.text: Press r to manually refresh, or check your connection.
